intro: Oldenlandia quadrangularis, commonly known as the four-angle grass or the stinging nettle vine, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its square-shaped stems, which are covered in fine hairs and can cause skin irritation upon contact. The plant produces small, white or yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, and its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly serrated edge. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in disturbed soils or along stream banks. The species is part of the Rubiaceae family, which includes many economically important plants.
